Award.AwardTitle: Studies on Signals and Images via the Fourier Transform
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop novel statistical methods that address some of the current challenges in analyzing spatio-temporal data frequently encountered in neuroimaging. One major application of this project is to identify features in brain signals that could differentiate healthy individuals from patients with neurological or mental diseases. The second application is to identify changes that take place in a brain signal during cognitive processing (e.g., while a human learns a new motor skill or while a rat learns risks and rewards in a controlled experiment). The third application is to identify biomarkers in brain signals that could predict a stroke patient's ability to recover loss of motor functionality. The approach used to solve these problems requires a study of the oscillatory patterns in these brain signals.

Motivated by these practical problems, statistical methods based on the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) are developed. The DFT gives an indication of the decomposition of variance in the time series. Under stationarity, the covariance of the DFT is sparse and thus a departure from sparsity is an indication of non-stationarity. Moreover, the covariance of the DFT can be utilized as a discriminator between classes of signals. Using the properties of the DFT, novel methods for (1) change-point detection in time series based on sparsity of the DFT, and (2) discrimination and classification of classes of time series based on the properties of the covariance of the DFT will be developed. The DFT will also be used to estimate the variance of functionals of the spectrum and test for serial correlation and stationarity in nonlinear time series. Validation for stationary spatial processes and non-stationary spatial processes using the two-dimensional DFT will also be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal in this project was to exploit subtle mathematical differences observed in certain transformations of data to draw useful conclusions about the world we observe. The fundamental tool we have used was the Fourier transform. The Fourier transform is a tool that is widely used in time series and signal processing for transforming signals observed over both space and time. It dates back at least a hundred year and is mainly used for detecting periodicities. However, it has the simple and elegant property that it can almost "decorrelate" certain types of data. By decorrelated we mean remove the linear dependence within a data set.  The aim in this project was to develop a deeper understanding of the Fourier transform and the way it is able decorrelate data. This has allowed us to develop several different data analyic techniques, which we summarize below. We have shown that the Fourier transform only decorrelates certain types of data. In particular if the signal is nonstationary (there are temporal or spatial changes), then the decorrelation property does not hold. It is this simple property that was the driving force of much the research in this project. We used the dichotomy of correlation verses no correlation to detect  stationary and nonstationary behaviour.Furthermore, understanding where the nonstationarity may manifest is often problematic. Thus we developedvisual tools for visualising the nonstationarity in complex systems such as spatial and spatio-temporal data. Detecting signals which are nonstationary is extremely important inmany applications. In particular, nonstationarity often suggests that an external intervention within the system. This is useful in a range of applications from detecting changes in neuronsin the brain and to detecting changes in climate. However, this is just one application of the decorrelation property.Many estimators involving dependent data are saddled with uncertainty that is extremely difficult to quantify.This makes the construction of margins of error and statistical tests extremely problematic. We have shown that the decorrelation property allows us to construct surrogate(or orthogonal samples) corresponding to certain estimators. Once constructed the orthogonal sampleacts as a simple proxy for the uncertainty in the estimator. It transpired that such a technique can be used to analyze both spatial and temporal data.To summarise, in this project we have shown that simple transformations of dependent data can illuminate our understanding of the mechanisms which drive the process.
